articles.headline: Commuting Puzzle: Why Driving Is Rewarded Over Taking the Bus
articles.snippet: The pretax commuter benefit has taken different forms over the years, and the 2012 version will benefit car drivers more than bus and train riders.
articles.abstract: The pretax commuter benefit has taken different forms over the years, and the 2012 version will benefit car drivers more than bus and train riders.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the story of a tax break that can be worth four figures each year per household. And it’s not just any four-figure break.

articles.headline: Rousing Russia With a Phrase
articles.snippet: Aleksei Navalny has aroused Russians angry over what they say were fraudulent parliamentary elections, rebranding Vladimir V. Putin’s United Russia party as “the party of swindlers and thieves.”
articles.abstract: Aleksei Navalny has aroused Russians angry over what they say were fraudulent parliamentary elections, rebranding Vladimir V. Putin’s United Russia party as “the party of swindlers and thieves.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The man most responsible for the extraordinary burst of antigovernment activism here over the past week will not speak at a rally planned for Saturday, or even attend it, because he is in prison.

articles.headline: A Risk Once Unthinkable
articles.snippet: MF Global had internal controls and a chief compliance officer, so how did it lose $1.2 billion of customer funds that were, by law, untouchable?
articles.abstract: MF Global had internal controls and a chief compliance officer, so how did it lose $1.2 billion of customer funds that were, by law, untouchable?
articles.lead_paragraph: Are customer accounts at brokerage firms safe?

articles.headline: With Lobbying Blitz, For-Profit Colleges Diluted New Rules
articles.snippet: A ferocious pushback led Education Department and White House officials to relax an effort to cut off the huge flow of federal financial aid to unfit educational programs.
articles.abstract: A ferocious pushback led Education Department and White House officials to relax an effort to cut off the huge flow of federal financial aid to unfit educational programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last year, the Obama administration vowed to stop for-profit colleges from luring students with false promises. In an opening volley that shook the $30 billion industry, officials proposed new restrictions to cut off the huge flow of federal aid to unfit programs.

articles.headline: Swatch, Supplier to Rivals, Now Aims to Cut Them Off
articles.snippet: In January, Swatch, the Swiss timepiece maker, will cut back its sales of watch components to competitors, a move that is fanning resentment of Swatch’s clout and size in the industry.
articles.abstract: In January, Swatch, the Swiss timepiece maker, will cut back its sales of watch components to competitors, a move that is fanning resentment of Swatch’s clout and size in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Swatch Group may be best known for its playful, plastic watches. But it also produces mechanical movements and other watch components that it sells to most of its rival timepiece makers.

articles.headline: An A.T.V. With Extra Room, and Maybe More Risks, Too
articles.snippet: The ability to carry passengers has sent the popularity of side-by-side off-road vehicles soaring, but despite roll bars and seat belts, safety concerns are rising.
articles.abstract: The ability to carry passengers has sent the popularity of side-by-side off-road vehicles soaring, but despite roll bars and seat belts, safety concerns are rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: They started out decades ago as handy vehicles for farmers and builders to haul things like lumber and fertilizer.

articles.headline: Thousands Sterilized, a State Weighs Restitution
articles.snippet: A task force is calculating North Carolina’s obligation to the estimated 7,600 victims of its eugenics program from 1933 to 1977, many of them poor and uneducated.
articles.abstract: A task force is calculating North Carolina’s obligation to the estimated 7,600 victims of its eugenics program from 1933 to 1977, many of them poor and uneducated.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINWOOD, N.C. — Charles Holt, 62, spreads a cache of vintage government records across his trailer floor. They are the stark facts of his state-ordered sterilization.

articles.headline: For Chase, a TV Show to Promote Its Charity
articles.snippet: In a gambit to polish its image — JPMorgan Chase will sponsor the “American Giving Awards,” an event that will be televised on Saturday and will profile recipients of Chase donations.
articles.abstract: In a gambit to polish its image — JPMorgan Chase will sponsor the “American Giving Awards,” an event that will be televised on Saturday and will profile recipients of Chase donations.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a television network broadcasts an awards show created by a multinational bank’s marketers, what is it? An advertisement? A tribute to deserving charities? An entertainment spectacle?

articles.headline: Rally Defying Putin’s Party Draws Tens of Thousands
articles.snippet: Mass protests on the streets of Moscow forced the Kremlin to confront a level of public discontent that has not been seen in Russia in decades.
articles.abstract: Mass protests on the streets of Moscow forced the Kremlin to confront a level of public discontent that has not been seen in Russia in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of Russians took to the streets in Moscow on Saturday shouting “Putin is a thief” and “Russia without Putin,” forcing the Kremlin to confront a level of public discontent that has not been seen here since Vladimir V. Putin first became president 12 years ago.

articles.headline: The Fattest or the Fittest?
articles.snippet: Reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington.
articles.abstract: Reducing the perils of gargantuan institutions — and the threat to taxpayers — is an idea that seems to be taking hold in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELIMINATING the benefits reaped by institutions that are too politically powerful and interconnected to fail has been an elusive goal in the aftermath of the credit crisis. Institutions most likely to receive assistance from the federal government if they become troubled — behemoths like  Bank of America or Wells Fargo — have grown only larger in recent years. Efforts to pare down these banks have met well-financed resistance among policy makers.

articles.headline: Quality of Air? That’s as Murky as Western Sky
articles.snippet: The question of how clean the air is in the American West is getting harder to answer, scientists say, with implications for public health, the environment and tourism.
articles.abstract: The question of how clean the air is in the American West is getting harder to answer, scientists say, with implications for public health, the environment and tourism.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Oh say, can you see across the Grand Canyon? Not as well as you used to on some days.

articles.headline: The Lasting Shadow of Bernie Madoff
articles.snippet: Three years after his arrest, the mastermind of Ponzi schemes still haunts his victims, his family and himself.
articles.abstract: Three years after his arrest, the mastermind of Ponzi schemes still haunts his victims, his family and himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I made the tragic mistake of trying to change the way money was managed and was successful at the start, but lost my way after a while and refused to admit that I failed.”

articles.headline: In Euro Era, Opening Bell Is a 2:30 A.M. Alarm
articles.snippet: Traders who once woke up at dawn to get an edge are rising in the dead of night to buy and sell credit default swaps from their bedrooms.
articles.abstract: Traders who once woke up at dawn to get an edge are rising in the dead of night to buy and sell credit default swaps from their bedrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the European debt crisis roils the markets, American traders who once awoke at dawn are now rising in the dead of night to gain an edge when business begins in London, Paris and Frankfurt.

articles.headline: Beyond Guantánamo, a Web of Prisons for Terrorism Inmates
articles.snippet: An archipelago of federal prisons that stretches across the country houses far more men convicted in terrorism cases than the shrunken population of the controversial prison in Cuba.
articles.abstract: An archipelago of federal prisons that stretches across the country houses far more men convicted in terrorism cases than the shrunken population of the controversial prison in Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is the other Guantánamo, an archipelago of federal prisons that stretches across the country, hidden away on back roads. Today, it houses far more men convicted in terrorism cases than the shrunken population of the prison in Cuba that has generated so much debate.

articles.headline: Race Reshaped, Rivals Target Gingrich in G.O.P. Debate
articles.snippet: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich took fire for most of the evening and seemed to relish his new role as the leading Republican candidate in the field.
articles.abstract: Three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Newt Gingrich took fire for most of the evening and seemed to relish his new role as the leading Republican candidate in the field.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Newt Gingrich offered a robust defense of his views on the Middle East, his lucrative work after leaving Congress and his conservative credentials during a spirited debate here on Saturday night as his Republican presidential rivals urged voters to take a hard look at his candidacy.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Boosted by Putin, Russia’s Middle Class Turns on Him
articles.snippet: A decade of growth under Vladimir V. Putin, now Russia’s prime minister, has created a class of wealthy urban professionals who are not afraid to express their political frustration.
articles.abstract: A decade of growth under Vladimir V. Putin, now Russia’s prime minister, has created a class of wealthy urban professionals who are not afraid to express their political frustration.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Here is the rub for Vladimir V. Putin: The people who stood outside the Kremlin on Saturday, chanting epithets directed at him, are the ones who have prospered greatly during his 12 years in power.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Athhilezar? Watch Your Fantasy World Language
articles.snippet: Hollywood is driving demand for constructed languages, complete with grammatical rules, a written alphabet (hieroglyphics are acceptable) and enough vocabulary for basic conversations.
articles.abstract: Hollywood is driving demand for constructed languages, complete with grammatical rules, a written alphabet (hieroglyphics are acceptable) and enough vocabulary for basic conversations.
articles.lead_paragraph: At his best friend’s wedding reception on the California coast, David J. Peterson stood to deliver his toast as best man. He held his Champagne glass high and shouted “Hajas!” The 50 guests raised their glasses and chanted “Hajas!” in unison.

articles.headline: Fed to Weigh Publishing a Forecast on Rates
articles.snippet: When the Fed’s policy-making committee convenes on Tuesday, it will consider the idea of publishing a regular forecast of its future decisions on interest rates.
articles.abstract: When the Fed’s policy-making committee convenes on Tuesday, it will consider the idea of publishing a regular forecast of its future decisions on interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s decision three years ago to reduce short-term interest rates to nearly zero made a splash, both because the Fed had never pushed rates so low and because it said that it planned to keep rates near zero “for some time.”

articles.headline: As Kindle Fire Faces Critics, Remedies Are Promised
articles.snippet: Amazon does not say so, but the company is soon likely to release an improved version of the device, which is generating a lot of negative customer feedback.
articles.abstract: Amazon does not say so, but the company is soon likely to release an improved version of the device, which is generating a lot of negative customer feedback.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Kindle Fire, Amazon’s heavily promoted tablet, is less than a blazing success with many of its early users. The most disgruntled are packing the device up and firing it back to the retailer.

articles.headline: Detainee in Iraq Poses a Dilemma as U.S. Exit Nears
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is wrestling with a decision about whether to turn Ali Musa Daqduq over to the Iraqi government or to find a way to take him with the military as it withdraws.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is wrestling with a decision about whether to turn Ali Musa Daqduq over to the Iraqi government or to find a way to take him with the military as it withdraws.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As United States troops prepare to exit Iraq at the end of the month, the Obama administration is facing a significant dilemma over what to do with the last remaining detainee held by the American military in Iraq.

articles.headline: Among Gingrich’s Passions, a Doomsday Vision
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich is ringing alarm bells over a type of nuclear attack called the electromagnetic pulse, which some scientists say is far-fetched.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich is ringing alarm bells over a type of nuclear attack called the electromagnetic pulse, which some scientists say is far-fetched.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newt Gingrich, the Republican presidential hopeful, wants you to know that as commander in chief he is ready to confront one of the most nightmarish of doomsday scenarios: a nuclear blast high above the United States that would instantly throw the nation into a dark age.

articles.headline: A Stark Step Away From Europe
articles.snippet: A move by David Cameron to protect the City of London underscores a growing distance between Britain and the European Union.
articles.abstract: A move by David Cameron to protect the City of London underscores a growing distance between Britain and the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Has Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain hurt his country’s powerful financial services industry more than he has helped it?

articles.headline: When Truth Survives Free Speech
articles.snippet: A defamation suit that seemed to be an example of a blogger being unfairly denied the protections of a journalist was actually something else entirely.
articles.abstract: A defamation suit that seemed to be an example of a blogger being unfairly denied the protections of a journalist was actually something else entirely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, a story came across my desk that seemed to suggest that a blogger had been unfairly nailed with a $2.5 million defamation award after a judge refused to give her standing as a journalist. A businessman who was the target of the blogger’s inquiries brought the suit.

articles.headline: Occupy Video Showcases Live Streaming
articles.snippet: The huge amount of video being produced by the Occupy Wall Street movement could represent a watershed moment for companies offering live streaming.
articles.abstract: The huge amount of video being produced by the Occupy Wall Street movement could represent a watershed moment for companies offering live streaming.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brad Hunstable started Ustream, an online video platform, with a fellow West Point graduate back in 2007 to help American troops overseas communicate with multiple friends and family members at the same time. It was not long before its uses extended well beyond the military.

articles.headline: Chronic Pain for the Euro
articles.snippet: With mounds of European debt due to be refinanced early next year, the crisis is far from over, and there are risks even in getting the Brussels deal ratified.
articles.abstract: With mounds of European debt due to be refinanced early next year, the crisis is far from over, and there are risks even in getting the Brussels deal ratified.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The deal on Friday in Brussels to reformulate the rules of the euro zone has probably saved the shared currency for now — but there may be less to it than meets the eye.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: A Leader in the Cloud Gains Rivals
articles.snippet: Cloud computing, which Salesforce.com has been marketing for years, is now seen as such a good idea that I.B.M., SAP, Oracle and others are acquiring their own players.
articles.abstract: Cloud computing, which Salesforce.com has been marketing for years, is now seen as such a good idea that I.B.M., SAP, Oracle and others are acquiring their own players.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For over a decade, Marc Benioff has had to listen to dismissals of the company he founded, Salesforce.com, as a marginal player in the business software industry.

articles.headline: Russian Mogul Joins the Race Against Putin
articles.snippet: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a billionaire industrialist and owner of the New Jersey Nets, said he is seeking to fill a void in Russia’s opposition by challenging Vladimir V. Putin for the presidency.
articles.abstract: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, a billionaire industrialist and owner of the New Jersey Nets, said he is seeking to fill a void in Russia’s opposition by challenging Vladimir V. Putin for the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There were no balloons or streamers at the hastily arranged news conference on Monday where Mikhail D. Prokhorov announced that he would challenge Vladimir V. Putin in this spring’s presidential elections: just Mr. Prokhorov on the podium, looking grave.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Intel Sees Opportunity in Shortage of Drives
articles.snippet: The chip maker said fourth-quarter revenue would be lower than expected because of shortages of hard drives as a result of flooding in Thailand.
articles.abstract: The chip maker said fourth-quarter revenue would be lower than expected because of shortages of hard drives as a result of flooding in Thailand.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel will not let a good crisis go to waste.

articles.headline: Court to Weigh Arizona Statute on Immigration
articles.snippet: The Obama administration challenged parts of the tough immigration law in court, saying it could not be reconciled with federal immigration policies.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration challenged parts of the tough immigration law in court, saying it could not be reconciled with federal immigration policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the space of a month, the Supreme Court has thrust itself into the center of American political life, agreeing to hear three major cases that could help determine which party controls the House of Representatives and whether President Obama wins a second term.
